Viruses that affect asthma are acting on a complex and varied phenotype, and therefore the outcome of each infection can be quite varied. A simple linear cause-and-effect relationship between a viral infection and an asthmatic episode usually does not exist. Kochâ€™s modified postulates for infection-caused disease are:
The microorganism must be present in every case of the disease.
The microorganism must be isolated from a diseased organism and grown in pure culture.
The cultured microorganism should cause disease when introduced into a healthy organism.
The microorganism must be recovered from an inoculated, diseased experimental host.
